Are Haskell Functors actual Functors?

This is sibtitle

Posted on July 13, 2020 by Ramiro Leal
Tags: haskell, stuff

How are functors defined in haskell?

Are Haskell “functors” actual functors? Let’s take as an example the list instance of functor:This is the actual implemenetation used in the Haskell Prelude.

instance Functor [] where
  -- fmap ∷ (α → β) → [α] → [β]
  fmap _ []     = [] 
  fmap f (x:xs) = fx : fmap f xs

In order to better understand if [] is a functor, we first need to note that a functor \(F : \mathbf{C} \to \mathbf{D}\) can take different things as inputs: Objects and Arrows. Thus, \(F\) can be thought of as a two functions in one:

f ∷ Int → Int
f x = x

This is a citation [1]

This is a citation [1]

ghci> take 4 [1..]
fmap _ []     = [] fmap f (x:xs) = fx : fmap f xs fmap _ []     = [] fmap f (x:xs) = fx : fmap f xs

[1] Richard Bird and Ralf Hinze. 2003. Functional pearl trouble shared is trouble halved. In Proceedings of the 2003 acm sigplan workshop on haskell (Haskell ’03), Association for Computing Machinery, New York, NY, USA, 1–6. DOI:https://doi.org/10.1145/871895.871896
